sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying motor
message_1: A motor has 200 turns of wire in a circular loop with a radius of 5 cm. The motor carries a current of 5 A. Calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a single circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * N) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, N is the number of turns, and R is the radius of the loop.

In this case, we have:

I = 5 A
N = 200 turns
R = 5 cm = 0.05 m

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * 200) / (2 * 0.05 m)

B = (4π × 10^(-7) * 5 * 200) / 0.1

B = (4π × 10^(-7) * 1000) / 0.1

B = 4π × 10^(-4) T

B ≈ 1.2566 × 10^(-3) T

So, the magnetic field at the center of the loop is approximately 1.2566 × 10^(-3) T or 1.2566 mT.
